verbatim_example: I've been messing around with heroin and bupe since about April - my most recent relapse. IV dope user for ~8 years. I became hooked mainly to the bupe this time, with occasional dope hits. It's been just over a week without bupe. Tried to cold turkey but failed.
I've tried everything (meetings, rehab, detox, moving, sponsorship) but sooner or later I come back to habited and looking for a way out.. **Should I consider methadone long term?**

I FINALLY managed to stop using H and got on Subs
I spend maybe half the year in my addiction and half of it on subbies

On the other side of that coin the moments of joy have been incredibly real and unexpected. Meeting a woman (also the source of my biggest pain), rediscovering music and pushing myself to do things I never thought I'd get to, peer support work at the centre where I got clean, service positions in NA / CA - all this in under a year.
now I am trying to stabilize on Kratom
I will use as much Kratom as needed to get through jumping off DHC
I was on a large benzo/opiate habit and got off both 3 weeks to the day... I started to feel stabilized on Kratom
I've only got 5 months but I'm telling you. I'm so excited to wake up each day doing something I love. Helping other addicts who are suffering.
I am happy to be here, sober

I've got 4 months clean and sober - the idea of being in pain just riles me up. I know that there is no chance in hell that I can have any opiates without coming unhinged.
I kicked a 4 year IV meth habit. I went from being a junkie to being a contributing member of society, with a great family and career.

I've been sober, my husband has the pills stashed, there were only 16 5mg Percocet given to me and I've only taken 6, total. (2 at a time) Never took them during the day, never got loaded at that dose and yet I still feel disappointed in myself.
I was able to put together a year, which turned into a year and a half (where I am currently), and now I am truly beginning to realize that there is a major difference in my thought process overall.

I remember when I was using that if I was honest with myself, the answer was always that I wanted to change things and wanted to stop- but the next thought would be that I needed to make a plan first, and certainly couldn’t start right then, because I wanted to do it ‘right’.

Myself as well as the large majority of opiate users I have met along my journey through recovery all have almost the same story... They put you on Suboxone, or methadone, or any other maintenance drug.

Been trying to pick up on hobbies like sneakers, movies, working on my car, etc. Shits been going pretty well. I have good days and bad days. Been in a bit of a funk since right around my 90 days clean.

I've gotten out of little 90 day funk finally! Just been doing lots of meetings, therapy, step work, and hanging out with new as well as old friends. I'm extremely thankful for my sobriety. I dove head first into recovery and I have tried to put as much work into it as I did being a junkie.

I finally asked for help, and started being honest. Honest with my family, with my friends, with my therapist, and most importantly with myself. It was the first time that I truly accepted that I was indeed an addict, and that I couldn't do it by myself.
